Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone

ALLEGATION:
On 5/10/22, Youth B was physically assaulted by Youth A at the facility. There was
insufficient staff to stop the fight sooner. Youth A has significant injuries and is afraid
to return to the facility.
INVESTIGATION:
Received complaint on 05/12/2022 and investigated in collaboration with DHHS
Specialist.
I interviewed Youth B at school on 05/12/2022, in collaboration with the DHHS
Specialist. Youth B reported she lives in a group home with three other children. She
likes the staff and has a good relationship with all the girls except Youth A. She said
last week Youth A stole things from her room and they got into a fight. She and
Youth A got in another fight two days ago, because Youth A was teasing her about
her family, so she threw a cup a of water at her. She went to her bedroom and Youth
A followed her and hit her with a belt. She said there were two staff members, and
they were trying to stop the fight, but Youth A kept coming after her. Staff took the
belt away and Youth A then hit her on the arms with a hairbrush. She tried to choke
Youth A and Youth A punched her in the nose. Staff were able to separate them and
stop the fight. Her nose was bleeding, so staff gave her an ice pack for her nose.
Youth B pulled up her shirt sleeves and her arms had multiple bruises and scratch
marks. She reported there is usually three staff present but that evening there was
only two. Youth B reported not being afraid to go home but does not like that Youth
A is always starting fights with her.
I interviewed Youth A and Youth B’s Foster Care Specialist at the school on
05/12/2022, in collaboration with DHHS Specialist. She is the foster care worker for
both girls. She reported that the Chief Administrator notified her about the fight and
knows that there has been issues with both girls since their placement at the facility.
Youth B had a medical exam on 05/11/2022 and her exam was normal besides the
3

bruises on her arms. Youth A had a reevaluation by her psychiatrist, and they are
making changes to her medication. She reports Youth B was the first one placed at
the facility and has been instigating fights with Youth A. She is looking into finding
another placement for Youth A due to her aggressive behavior.
I interviewed School Administrator on 05/12/2022 at the school, in collaboration with
DHHS Specialist. She reported on 05/11/2022 the school nurse saw Youth because
she had a headache and was not feeling well. The school contacted the CA at the
facility and Youth B was picked up for her scheduled doctor appointment that
afternoon.
I interviewed Youth A at the facility on 05/12/2022, in collaboration with DHHS
Specialist. Youth A is 11 years old and is in the fifth grade. She has been at the
facility for one month. She said she feels safe and has a good relationship with all
the staff and youths except Youth B. She and Youth B got into it last week because
Youth B was teasing her during group therapy. On 05/10/22, Youth B threw water in
her face, so she punched Youth B in the face. She reported Youth B also punched
and kicked her, but she does not have any bruises or marks. She said staff
separated them and she went outside with staff to calm down. While she was
outside Youth B went into her bedroom and ripped her pictures. She went after
Youth B, punched her nose, and made her nose bleed. She said the staff were trying
to stop the fight, but she and Youth B kept fighting. She said at one point Youth B
stopped fighting, but she went to the kitchen to grab a fork and stab Youth B. She
reported CA blocked her from entering Youth B’s bedroom and Staff 1 kept trying to
calm her down. She finally calmed down and went to her bedroom. She said she has
been restrained once since placed at the facility. She expressed no worries or
concerns. She said she is getting enough to eat, gets her medication daily, and feels
safe.
I interviewed CA at Adrian Group Home on 05/12/2022, in collaboration with DHHS
Specialist. She reported the facility opened in March and they currently have four
youths. On 05/10/22 there were three staff scheduled to work the afternoon shift,
one staff member resigned, and another staff called in sick, so she filled in that shift.
She typically has two or three staff on second shift not including her. On the day in
question, they were within the ratio of 2:1, but they had a challenging time
separating the two youths that got into a fight. She said there was tension between
the two youths from an incident the week prior. On 05/10/22 during dinner Youth B
was antagonizing Youth A, so they started to argue. The situation escalated when
Youth A threatened Youth B, so she instructed the all the girls to go to their rooms.
Youth A and Youth B refused and charged at each other. They started hitting and
punching each other, so she and Staff 1 separated them. Youth A grabbed a belt
and was trying to hit Youth B. She and the other staff were trying to separate the two
girls again by blocking and taking objects away. Both youths were escalated and
extremely aggressive. Youth A kept trying to grab different objects (belt, hairbrush,
spoon,) to hit Youth B and Staff 1 kept taking the objects away. They were able to
separate the two youths multiple times, but they kept instigating and attacking each
4

other. It took about one hour to get the two girls under control and calm down. She
said Youth B’s nose was bleeding, so they helped clean her up and gave her an ice
pack. Youth B did not report any distress or pain after the fight. On 05/11/2022
Youth B had a medical exam, which was normal except for the bruising on her arms.
The youths were not restrained because there were only two staff on shift, and she
felt it would not be safe for the youths or staff if they restrained one of the youths.
She said there was an incident last week with both youths and they had three staff
on shift, so they were able to control the situation by each staff taking one youth into
another room. She has requested while the youths are at the facility that they have a
least three staff on second shift and she is going to keep the two youths separated.
I interviewed Staff 1 at the facility on 05/12/2022, in collaboration with DHHS
Specialist. Staff 1 has been employed at the facility for six months. She reported
there has been tension between Youth A and Youth B since last week. On 05/10/22
Youth B instigated the fight by teasing Youth A at dinner. She took Youth A’s seat at
the dinner table, and threw a cup of water at Youth A. She said that set off Youth A
and she charged at Youth B. She and the CA tried to separate and block the two
girls, but the two youths kept going after each other every time they separated them.
She said they could not restrain the two youths because they did not have enough
staff to ensure that the two youths would not go after each other. At one point she
got Youth A to go outside to calm down, but Youth B went to Youth A’s bedroom and
trashed it. Youth A was extremely angry and went after Youth B again. Youth A
punched Youth B in the face and gave her a bloody nose. They final got the two girls
separated and calmed down. She said they looked over Youth B and found she had
bruises, but she did not seem to be distress or seriously injured. They did give her
an ice pack for the nosebleed. She reported they typically have three staff on second
shift. She said they would have restrained Youth A if they had a third staff member
present.
Documents reviewed for the investigation:
 Well Child Exam report dated 05/11/2022. Youth B’s exam was normal except
for bruising on her arms. No medical treatment provided.
 Incident report, dated 05/10/2022, written by Staff 1. The report was
consistent with Staff 1’s interview.
 Facility’s policy for Physical Restraint Interventions.
 Facility’s Staff requirements and supervision.
5

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
The licensee shall have a sufficient number of
administrative, supervisory, social service, direct care, and
other staff on duty to perform the prescribed functions
required by these administrative rules and in the agency's
program statement and to provide for the continual needs,
protection, and supervision of residents.
ANALYSIS: Upon completion of the investigation, sufficient evidence was found
to confirm that agency staff failed to provide adequate supervision
of residents to ensure safety. Youth A and Youth B admitted they
got into a physical fight resulting in Youth B sustaining bruises
on her arms and a bloody nose. Staff confirmed they could not
adequately control the situation to prevent the two Youths from
hurting each other.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on the findings of this investigation, I recommend no change to the current
license status. This recommendation is contingent on the facility submitting an
acceptable corrective action plan for the noted violation.

sir_summary.summary: A physical fight between two youths (Youth A and Youth B) occurred at the Adrian Group Home on May 10, 2022, resulting in injuries including bruises and a bloody nose for Youth B. The investigation found that while staff-to-youth ratios were technically met, only two staff were on duty instead of the typical three, and they were insufficient to safely control the escalating situation or effectively separate the youths, leading to a prolonged altercation. The evidence substantiates a violation of staffing rules, placing clear culpability on the facility for failing to provide adequate supervision to ensure resident safety.

sir_violation_level.justification: The investigation substantiated a violation of staff sufficiency leading to inadequate supervision. This resulted in a prolonged physical assault between youths (Youth A and Youth B) involving hitting, punching, choking, and the use of objects (belt, hairbrush) as weapons, causing significant injuries including bruising and a bloody nose. The incident constitutes youth-on-youth violence, a criterion under the 'Safety and Violence' category for severe SIRs.
